grinder_guide.title: How to Choose a Coffee Grinder: Complete Guide
grinder_guide.subtitle: The most important investment in coffee equipment
grinder_guide.p_1: A good grinder matters more than your coffee maker. Ground coffee loses flavor within 15 minutes.
grinder_guide.p_why: Coffee is a complex mix of over 800 aromatic compounds. Once ground, these compounds start oxidizing and evaporating.
grinder_guide.blade_cons: Uneven grind, creates heat, not for espresso
grinder_guide.p_manual: Manual grinders offer excellent value — same burrs for less money. Ideal for travel.
grinder_guide.p_entry: Timemore C2, Hario Skerton — excellent choice for beginners. Price: $30-60.
grinder_guide.p_premium: Comandante, Fellow Ode — the best for demanding users. Price: $200+.
grinder_guide.p_conclusion: Invest in a good grinder — it's the most important purchase for great coffee at home.
grinder_guide.cta_title: Perfect grind starts with quality beans

espresso_mistakes.title: 7 Common Espresso Mistakes Made at Home
espresso_mistakes.subtitle: Why your espresso doesn't taste like the café
espresso_mistakes.p_1: Making great espresso at home is an art. Here are the most common mistakes that ruin your shot.
espresso_mistakes.h2_1: Why Your Espresso Doesn't Taste Right?
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake1: Espresso needs fresh beans, ideally 7-21 days after roasting. Ground coffee goes stale in hours.
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake2: Too coarse = sour, watery shot. Too fine = bitter, slow extraction. Aim for 25-30 seconds.
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake3: Apply even pressure (about 15kg) to create a level coffee bed.
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake4: Water should be 92-96°C. Too hot = bitter. Too cold = sour.
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake5: Use scales! Standard double shot: 18-20g in, 36-40g out in 25-30 seconds.
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake6: Old coffee oils go rancid. Clean portafilter and group head daily.
espresso_mistakes.p_mistake7: Hard or chlorinated water affects taste. Use filtered water.

turka_recipe.title: Turkish Coffee: Secrets of the Perfect Cezve
turka_recipe.subtitle: Ancient brewing tradition
turka_recipe.p_1: Turkish coffee is one of the oldest preparation methods, dating back to the 15th century Ottoman Empire.
turka_recipe.p_2: Turkish coffee requires the finest possible grind — finer than espresso.
turka_recipe.equipment1: Cezve (ibrik) — small copper or brass pot
turka_recipe.equipment2: Very finely ground coffee — almost powder
turka_recipe.equipment3: Cold water and sugar to taste
turka_recipe.step1: Add 1 heaping teaspoon (7g) of coffee per cup (60ml) to cezve
turka_recipe.step2: Add cold water and sugar to taste
turka_recipe.step3: Stir well, then place on low heat
turka_recipe.step4: Watch carefully as foam rises. Remove from heat before boiling.
turka_recipe.step5: Let foam settle, return to heat. Repeat 2-3 times.
turka_recipe.step6: Pour slowly into cups, preserving foam on top. Never stir!
turka_recipe.tip1: Use fresh, cold water for the smoothest result
turka_recipe.tip2: Low heat is key: patience creates the best foam
turka_recipe.tip3: Quality cezve matters — copper heats most evenly
turka_recipe.tip4: Let grounds settle 1-2 minutes before drinking

cold_brew.title: Cold Brew at Home: Simple Recipe

cold_brew_recipe.subtitle: Smooth, low-acid coffee for hot days
cold_brew_recipe.p_1: Cold brew is not just iced coffee. It steeps in cold water for 12-24 hours for a smooth, sweet concentrate.
cold_brew_recipe.p_difference: Iced coffee is brewed hot and cooled. Cold brew is never heated — it steeps in cold water 12-24 hours.
cold_brew_recipe.benefit4: Perfect for coffee cocktails and desserts
cold_brew_recipe.step2: Add to 1 liter cold filtered water
cold_brew_recipe.step5: Strain through fine mesh and paper filter
cold_brew_recipe.step6: Dilute concentrate 1:1 with water or milk
cold_brew_recipe.tip1: Use medium-dark roast for chocolate notes
cold_brew_recipe.tip2: Ethiopian naturals make incredible fruity cold brew

caffeine_myths.title: 5 Caffeine Myths Everyone Believes
caffeine_myths.subtitle: What's true and what's fiction
caffeine_myths.intro: Coffee and caffeine are surrounded by myths. Let's separate facts from fiction.
caffeine_myths.h3_1: Myth 1: Dark Roast Has More Caffeine
caffeine_myths.h3_2: Myth 2: Espresso Has the Most Caffeine
caffeine_myths.myth1_text: Light roast actually has slightly more caffeine. Roasting burns off caffeine, though the difference is minimal.
caffeine_myths.myth2_text: One espresso has ~63mg caffeine, while 350ml filter coffee has ~120mg. Volume matters!
caffeine_myths.myth3_text: While caffeine is a mild diuretic, the water in coffee more than compensates. Coffee counts toward daily hydration.
caffeine_myths.myth4_text: This old wives' tale has no scientific basis. Studies show no link between coffee and growth.
caffeine_myths.myth5_text: Decaf still contains 2-15mg caffeine per cup. If you're very sensitive, it may still affect you.
caffeine_myths.truth_text: Moderate coffee consumption (3-4 cups daily) is linked to various health benefits. Listen to your body and enjoy responsibly.

coffee_storage.title: How to Store Coffee Properly: 5 Essential Rules
coffee_storage.subtitle: Preserve freshness and aroma
coffee_storage.p_1: Coffee is a delicate product. Improper storage can ruin even the best specialty beans in days.
coffee_storage.p_2: Oxygen causes oxidation and stale flavors
coffee_storage.p_6: Use containers with one-way valves or vacuum-sealed bags
coffee_storage.p_7: A kitchen cabinet away from the stove is ideal
coffee_storage.p_temp: Don't refrigerate! Temperature changes cause condensation.
coffee_storage.p_freeze: If you must freeze beans, do it once and use immediately after thawing.

v60_guide.title: Perfect V60: Step-by-Step Recipe from a Barista

how_to_brew_v60.subtitle: Complete pour-over guide
how_to_brew_v60.p_1: V60 is one of the most popular pour-over methods that reveals the full potential of specialty coffee.
how_to_brew_v60.p_2: 15g coffee : 250ml water (1:16.6). This ratio works great for most specialty coffees.
how_to_brew_v60.p_3: Medium-fine grind, like table salt. Total time: 2:30-3:00.
how_to_brew_v60.p_4: Rinse filter with hot water — removes paper taste and preheats.
how_to_brew_v60.p_5: Pour 30-45ml water and wait 30-45 seconds. You'll see CO2 escaping.
how_to_brew_v60.p_6: Add water in slow concentric circles from center to edge.
how_to_brew_v60.step2: Add ground coffee and create small well in center
how_to_brew_v60.step5: Let drain completely. Total time should be around 2:30-3:00.
how_to_brew_v60.tip1: Water temperature: 92-96°C. Light roast needs hotter water.
how_to_brew_v60.tip2: Pour slowly and evenly. Avoid pouring directly on filter.
how_to_brew_v60.tip3: Gently swirl after bloom for even extraction.

light_vs_dark.title: Light vs Dark Roast: Which to Choose?
light_vs_dark.subtitle: Understanding roast levels and their impact on flavor
light_vs_dark.p_1: Roast level dramatically affects the taste of your coffee.
light_vs_dark.p_2: Bright acidity, floral and fruity notes, tea-like body. Original bean character shines through.
light_vs_dark.p_3: Bold, smoky, chocolatey notes. Lower acidity, fuller body.
light_vs_dark.p_4: Light roast has slightly more caffeine per scoop. Dark beans expand, so fewer per serving.
light_vs_dark.p_5: Light: pour-over, Aeropress. Dark: espresso, French press.
light_vs_dark.p_6: Choose based on your taste preferences and brewing method.
light_vs_dark.light_best: Best for: pour-over, Aeropress, those who appreciate complex flavors.
light_vs_dark.dark_best: Best for: espresso, French press, lovers of traditional coffee taste.

natural_washed.title: Natural vs Washed: How Processing Affects Taste

natural_vs_washed.subtitle: The journey from cherry to bean
natural_vs_washed.p_1: Before coffee reaches your cup, the fruit must be removed from the bean. How this is done affects the final flavor.
natural_vs_washed.p_2: Cherries are pulped, fermented to remove mucilage, washed, and dried.
natural_vs_washed.washed_flavor: Result: clean, bright, consistent flavors. True terroir of the bean shines through.
natural_vs_washed.washed_regions: Common in: Colombia, Kenya, most of Central America
natural_vs_washed.natural_process: Whole cherries dry in the sun for weeks. Fruit ferments around the bean.
natural_vs_washed.natural_flavor: Result: fruity, wine-like, sweet, complex. Can be controversial.
natural_vs_washed.honey_process: Depulped but not fully washed. Some mucilage remains during drying.
natural_vs_washed.honey_flavor: Sweet and fruity but cleaner than naturals. Best of both worlds.
natural_vs_washed.conclusion: Washed coffees are versatile and consistent. Naturals are for adventure and uniqueness. Try both!

water_for_coffee.title: What Water Do You Need for Perfect Coffee?
water_for_coffee.subtitle: 98% of your cup is water
water_for_coffee.p_1: You can have the best beans in the world, but bad water will ruin them.
water_for_coffee.p_2: Water is a solvent that extracts flavor compounds. Its mineral content determines what gets extracted.
water_for_coffee.problem1: Too soft (distilled): Not enough minerals for extraction. Flat, empty coffee.
water_for_coffee.problem2: Too hard: Excess minerals block aromatics. Chalky taste.
water_for_coffee.solution1: Filtered pitcher (Brita etc.) — simple and effective.
water_for_coffee.solution2: Low-mineral bottled water — alternative for enthusiasts.
water_for_coffee.cta_title: Water matters — try with our specialty coffee

ethiopia_origin.subtitle: History and Traditions
ethiopia_origin.p_1: Ethiopia is the birthplace of Arabica coffee.
ethiopia_origin.p_2: Kaldi the shepherd noticed his goats dancing after eating berries.
ethiopia_origin.p_4: The traditional ceremony is an important part of the culture.

sidamo_guide.title: Coffee from Sidamo Region: Complete Guide
sidamo_guide.subtitle: The Heart of Ethiopian Coffee
sidamo_guide.p_1: Sidamo is a vast and diverse coffee region.
sidamo_guide.p_3: Sidamo includes many subregions: Guji, Yirgacheffe, and others.
sidamo_guide.p_4: Balanced, fruity, with notes of berries and chocolate.
sidamo_guide.p_5: Medium roast for balancing acidity and body.

what_is_specialty.title: What is Specialty Coffee and Why Does It Cost More?
what_is_specialty.subtitle: The Difference You Can Taste
what_is_specialty.p_1: Specialty is not marketing. It is a score of 80+ from SCA.
what_is_specialty.p_2: SCA grades on a 100-point scale. 80+ = specialty.
what_is_specialty.p_3: Selective picking, quality processing, fresh roasting.
what_is_specialty.p_4: Commercial coffee = bitterness. Specialty = fruits, flowers, chocolate.
what_is_specialty.p_5: Once you try specialty, regular coffee will seem boring.
what_is_specialty.cta_title: Discover the World of Specialty Coffee

yirgacheffe_region.title: Coffee from Yirgacheffe Region: Why Is It Special?
yirgacheffe_region.subtitle: Introduction to Legendary Terroir
yirgacheffe_region.p_1: Yirgacheffe is one of the most famous coffee zones in the world.
yirgacheffe_region.p_2: Southern Ethiopia, Gedeo Zone. 1700-2200m above sea level.
yirgacheffe_region.p_3: Climate, soil, and traditional farming create a unique taste.
yirgacheffe_region.p_4: Bright, floral, citrusy. Bergamot, jasmine, lemon.

aeropress_recipes.title: 3 Champion AeroPress Recipes
aeropress_recipes.subtitle: Proven recipes from winners
aeropress_recipes.intro: AeroPress is incredibly versatile. Here are three recipes from World AeroPress Championship winners.
aeropress_recipes.recipe1_steps: Inverted method. Pour water, stir 10 times, wait 1:00, flip and press in 30 seconds.
aeropress_recipes.recipe2_steps: Standard method. Bloom 30s, add remaining water, press after 2:00.
aeropress_recipes.recipe3_steps: Pour everything at once, don't stir, start pressing at 45s, finish by 1:00.
aeropress_recipes.tip: Experiment! Every coffee is unique, and the best recipe is the one you like most.
